Guano was a major source of agricultural fertilizer until the Haber process made cheap nitrogen fertilizer possible. Now so much of it being applied to our industrial agricultural lands, the runoff is polluting both surface and groundwater with nitrates threatening our drinking water supply. Regenerative agriculture would go a long ways toward solving this water pollution problem as well as sequestering carbon in the soil to reduce atmospheric CO2.

EXCEPT FOR THE MONGOLS!!!
queue the raid-roll

Ghengis Kahn and the first few of his successors set up conservation forests across their empire. They did so, also for economic reasons. If there were food shortages, as is common after a land is conquered, the local populace would often wipe out any wild game nearby for food.
To combat this, the Mongols incentivized protecting various forests and species by paying some of the locals to be 'rangers' and they actually set up game laws for population management -- including protection during breeding seasons and winter range protection from development.

Now, that is according to Marco Polo's accounts... So take it for what it's worth.
